results.title: A Child's voice
results.creator_credit: B.A.C. Films Ltd (Ireland), Roland Hill and Kieran Hickey
results.brief_description: A tale of suspense. Three nights a week, Ainsley Rupert Macreadie writes and broadcasts chilling and intriguing tales of horror to rapt audiences. But his latest cruel narrative becomes a reality when the character of the boy involved refuses to obey the writer’s commands, and Macreadie discovers that he is the victim of the kind of terror which until now he has reserved for others. Starring T.P. McKenna as Ainsley Rupert Macreadie, June Tobin as the child. Written by David Thomson and narrated by Valentine Dyall. (Awards: First Prize Short Fiction Category - Chicago International Film Festival, 1978; Festival Choice - London Film Festival, 1978) Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: A Child's visit to the dentist
results.brief_description: Designed to allay children’s fear of the dentist and all that dentists represent, by following a five-fear-old on her first visit to the dentist. Outlines the function of various people working in the surgery, as well as explaining the purposes of X-ray machines, drills, scrapers, etc.

results.title: A Child's place
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Dick Foster and Eurfron Gwynne Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Parents and Children”.
Looks at the system of daycare for young children in Israel, USSR, China and Sweden.The film asks “Where are the children? Who are they with? and what are they doing?”.

results.title: A Child's Christmas in Wales by Dylan Thomas
results.brief_description: Using still photographs, this film shows life in Wales, illustrating Dylan Thomas’s recorded reading of his reminiscences about Christmas in his home country. Children play tricks on their elders, the adults enjoy the food and drink and even the local fire brigade becomes involved.

results.title: A Child
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Illustrates the importance of a teacher’s observation of individual behaviour in the classroom situation. An indecisive child is directed to pursue an activity through one-to-one contact with the teacher.

results.title: A Chemical feast
results.creator_credit: Benchmark Films, Penny Bernstein and Jack Sameth
results.brief_description: Presents a humorous look at the chemical composition of a lemon meringue pie and the unit value of four convenience foods. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: A Charles Dickens christmas
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Dramatizes incidents from Charles Dickens’ novel “The Pickwick Papers”, recounting the cross-country winter coach trip of Mr. Pickwick and his friends and their attendance at christmas festivities at Dingley Dell Farm. Includes reproductions of some of Robert Seymour’s original illustrations.

results.title: A Changing view of the change of life
results.creator_credit: Dynamic Productions, Walter Lowendahl and Hy Kalus
results.brief_description: Many questions relating to menopause are answered in this candid and informative film for women of all ages, and their families. Modern medical research has made startling discoveries about this period in a woman’s life and these have altered the traditional concepts about menopause. The film presents new attitudes and shows how doctors are dealing with the physical and emotional problems.

results.title: A Changing Perspective
results.brief_description: This film covers the widening interests of the Australian Paper Mills company. An historical background is given and the present main interests of the company, forestry, paper and pulp are documented. New projects include a diverse range of activities such as paper, plastic and metal packaging

results.title: A Changing culture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
David Gulpilil has become a success in the white man’s world, through his acting ability and leadership of a dance troupe. Yet he prefers to live in a traditional manner with his people in Arnhem Land, making brief forays into western society in order to publicise their plight and demonstrate the richness of their culture. Charmaine Green is a linguist student at the Australian National University. When she visits her family in Mullewa, W.A. and observes the hopeless life they lead on the fringes of western society, she feels that she cannot return there permanently, although she is determined not to deny her Aboriginality in spite of her light skin.
